message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of dizziness and passed out, which suggests a cardiac cause. The presence of a grade 3/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a systolic murmur at the apex, which disappear with passive leg elevation, suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. None of the other options have a murmur that disappears with passive leg elevation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has had episodes of dizziness and a grade 3/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and the apex, which disappears with passive leg elevation, suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Prolonged QT interval is not typically associated with syncope, and there is no mention of arrhythmia. Bicuspid aortic valve can lead to aortic stenosis, but there is no indication of this in the patient's case. Mitral valve prolapse can cause palpitations, but there is no evidence of this in the patient's case either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s episodes of dizziness and the presence of a grade 3/6 systolic murmur and a systolic murmur at the apex suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy as the most likely cause. Prolonged QT interval is associated with arrhythmias but there is no mention of any ECG abnormalities. Bicuspid aortic valve and mitral valve prolapse can also cause murmurs but are less likely to be associated with syncope and dizziness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including brief loss of consciousness and dizziness while exercising, coupled with the presence of grade 3/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a systolic murmur at the apex, both of which disappear with passive leg elevation, suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy as the most likely cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a systolic murmur at the apex disappearing with passive leg elevation, along with a history of dizziness with exercise, suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy as the most likely cause. Prolonged QT interval, bicuspid aortic valve, and mitral valve prolapse are not usually associated with these types of murmurs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of dizziness with exercise and has murmur on examination, which suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Prolonged QT interval and mitral valve prolapse are less likely to cause syncope with physical activity. Bicuspid aortic valve can cause a murmur but usually not with leg elevation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a grade 3/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a systolic murmur at the apex, both of which disappear with passive leg elevation. This is a classic presentation of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Prolonged QT interval causes arrhythmias but does not cause systolic murmurs. Bicuspid aortic valve causes aortic stenosis and not systolic murmurs at the sternal border. Mitral valve prolapse causes a mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur but not at the left lower sternal border.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and exam findings suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can cause sudden cardiac death during exercise due to arrhythmia, and syncope due to outflow tract obstruction. Prolonged QT interval can cause arrhythmia but there are no ECG findings mentioned. Bicuspid aortic valve can cause aortic stenosis but the murmur disappears with leg elevation, suggesting it’s functional. Mitral valve prolapse can cause a murmur but it’s unlikely to disappear with leg elevation.

These are classic signs of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. None of the other options fit the patient’s symptoms.

None of the other options match the symptoms or examination findings.
